answers.author: Alexandra Iannolo
answers.text:
Hello, 
I found that the City of Davis, California has an extensive system of bikeways which they use a waiver for. You may want to contact them directly for more information about their policies and procedures. Below I have included a link to their biking homepage and that waiver.
http://cityofdavis.org/bicycles/
http://cityofdavis.org/bicycles/pdfs/Rodeo-Permission-Form.pdf
I found two examples of groups using public property that worked together with local government on a liability waiver.
One is for a skate park in Santa Monica, California called The Cove. While technically a private park they make use of public infrastructure like curbs. You can see their waiver below.
http://www01.smgov.net/comm_progs/skatepark/Release.pdf
The other is an international waiver for diving in the Marshall Islands. They dive off natural cliffs so even though it is a private organization they must work with local government for a waiver.
http://www.visitrongelap.com/pdf/divingliabilitywaiverr.pdf 
For more general information about local government liability you can see the link below to the United States Department of Transportation, Federal Highway Administration.  They offer suggestions on how to word liability waivers and policies regarding trails or paths in your community.
http://www.fhwa.dot.gov/environment/rectrails/rwt/section4.htm
Ali Iannolo
Knowledge Network Intern
aiannolo@ICMA.org

author: Patty Brescia
text:
We have a local group of adults who participate in weekly road bike rides about once a week in our city and the surrounding area. There are a couple of volunteer leaders who  send out the annoucements about upcoming rides to the email list. The volunteer leaders have recently approached our Community Center staff asking if they (the volunteer leaders) have any liability for the participants of the rides, and if they should be using liability releases. The rides are free, and the only involvement of the City is to run an annual annoucement in our summer program brochure, and contact information for new participants. 
My question is: Does anyone have a liabiliy release that can be used by an informal group that is not affiliated with a city, or other entity? Is it recommended that they use one, or better to avoid using one?
Thank you,
Patty Brescia,
Senior Programs Manager
City of Wilsonville
title: Cycling group liability release - City of Wilsonville
